The plunge in Facebook's shares comes after it delivered an earnings report it reported earnings that were weaker than analysts expected, showing slowing user growth, capped by a weaker-than-expected outlook for revenues as it revamps its business model in the face of its Cambridge Analytica scandal.

Facebook Inc.'s shares tumbled Thursday, with the Menlo Park, Calif.-based social media behemoth recording the worst one-day skid in its history and the steepest one-session loss of value in a U.S. public company ever, according to WSJ Market Data Group, tracking the top 25 large-cap companies.

That would represent the biggest loss of value in a company since Intel Corp. INTC, -4.40% lost about $90 billion in one day about 18 years ago, with Microsoft Corp.'s MSFT, -4.00% single-session $80 billion loss, also in 2000, ranking third.
Facebook shed about $120 billion in market capitalization in a single session, with the company's total value standing at about $510 billion, according to FactSet data.
The tech and internet-stock heavy Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, -3.05% meanwhile, fell by 1%, after notching its 25th all-time high of 2018 on Wednesday.
Facebook's stock FB, -1.58% fell nearly 19%--its ugliest single-session decline since it became a publicly traded entity May 18, 2012.
The company's stock-price drop, by dint of its market value, weighed on Wall Street equity benchmarks.
The S&P 500 index SPX, -2.33% lost 0.3%, with the technology sector producing the stiffest headwind.
Meanwhile, the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -2.24% closed up 113 points, or 0.4%, at 25,527.
